question: Should the United States use the Electoral College in presidential elections?

content.source_1: Alexander Hamilton, The Federalist No. 68 (1788). Primary-source defense of the Electoral College as a deliberative mechanism to guard against demagogues and foreign interference, suggesting the system creates a buffer against impulsive popular passions. https://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/fed68.asp
content.source_2: Allen C. Guelzo and James Hulme, “In Defense of the Electoral College,” National Affairs (2019). Argues the Electoral College reinforces federalism, compels broad, cross-regional coalition-building, and prevents domination by a few populous urban centers—benefits the authors say would be lost under a national popular vote. https://www.nationalaffairs.com/publications/detail/in-defense-of-the-electoral-college
content.source_3: FairVote, “Wrong-Way Winners” (analysis page, updated). Documents elections in which the popular vote winner lost the presidency (e.g., 1876, 1888, 2000, 2016), contending the Electoral College can thwart majority rule and undermine democratic legitimacy. https://www.fairvote.org/wrong_way_winners
content.source_4: Wesleyan Media Project, “Presidential Ads Top 700,000; Over 95% of Spots in 10 States” (Press Release, Nov. 3, 2016). Empirical evidence that campaign advertising and attention overwhelmingly concentrate in a small set of battleground states, indicating the Electoral College skews incentives and sidelines most voters. http://mediaproject.wesleyan.edu/releases/nov-3-2016/
content.source_5: Akhil Reed Amar, “The Troubling Reason the Electoral College Exists,” Time (Nov. 8, 2016). Historical critique asserting the Electoral College’s design was significantly shaped by slaveholding states’ interests, raising normative concerns about continuing the system today. https://time.com/4558510/electoral-college-history-slavery/
content.source_6: National Conference of State Legislatures (NCSL), “National Popular Vote” explainer (updated 2024). Describes the National Popular Vote Interstate Compact—enacted by states totaling over 200 electoral votes—as a viable state-based path to a national popular vote without amending the Constitution, challenging the necessity of retaining the Electoral College. https://www.ncsl.org/elections-and-campaigns/national-popular-vote
